[30] H. Zuo, W. Zhao, and P. Lin, Boundary treatment of linear multistep methods for hyperbolic conservation laws, Applied Mathematics and Computation, 425 (2022), p. 127079.

# Supplementary materials for the article "Boundary treatment for high-order IMEX Runge-Kutta Local Discontinuous Galerkin schemes for multidimensional nonlinear parabolic PDEs" 

The supplementary materials explicitly detail the boundary treatment procedure developed in Section 3, for the PDEs numerically solved in Section 5, considering the third-order IMEX scheme (2.19)-(2.23). Therefore, this section is intended to allow the reader to easily reproduce the numerical experiments of our article.
A. One-dimensional linear PDE with source terms. In this section, the boundary treatment strategy is applied to the following one-dimensional PDE presented in Section 5.1 of the article,

$$
u_{t}+\partial_{x} f(u)=\partial_{x} g\left(u_{x}\right)+h(u)
$$

where

$$
f(u)=-C u, \quad g\left(u_{x}\right)=D u_{x}, \quad h(u)=(D-1) u
$$

$C, D \in \mathbb{R}$ are the convection and diffusion coefficients, respectively. Besides, a time-dependent boundary condition $u_{\mid T}=\omega(t)$ is considered. Therefore,

$$
u_{t}=C u_{x}+(D-1) u+D u_{x x}
$$

On the one hand, for $D=1$, this PDE is the one presented in [26]. On the other hand, for $D \neq 1$, the PDE has a linear source term. Note that $u(x, t)=e^{-t} \sin (x+C t)$ is the exact solution of the problem.
A.1. First IMEX stage. The first IMEX stage (3.3) in this case, is

$$
\frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}=\left[C u_{x}^{n}+(D-1) u^{n}\right]+\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 1}\right]
$$

According (2.17), the explicit part is given by

$$
\xi^{n, i}(u, x, t)=C u_{x}^{n, i}+(D-1) u^{n, i}
$$

Then, equation (3.4) reads

$$
\frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}=C u_{x}^{n, 0}+(D-1) u^{n, 0}+u_{t}^{n, 1}-\left(C u_{x}^{n, 1}+(D-1) u^{n, 1}\right)
$$

Now, $u_{x}^{n, 1}$ is computed with (3.5), substituting and regrouping, the equation reduces to

$$
u^{n, 1}-u^{n}=\gamma \tau\left[u_{t}^{n, 1}-(D-1)\left(u^{n, 1}-u^{n}\right)\right]-\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left((D-1) u_{x}^{n}+C u_{x x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n, 1}\right)
$$

At this point, we apply Proposition 3.1, up to the first term to approximate $u_{x x x}^{n, 1}$. We end up with

$$
u^{n, 1}-u^{n}=\gamma \tau\left[u_{t}^{n, 1}-(D-1)\left(u^{n, 1}-u^{n}\right)\right]-\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left((D-1) u_{x}^{n}+C u_{x x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}\right)
$$

Finally, we need to solve the linear equation, we propose:

1. If we solve the equation analytically, which in this case is easy to solve for $u^{n, 1}$, the value at the first stage can finally be written as

$$
u^{n, 1}=u^{n}+\frac{1}{1+\gamma \tau(D-1)}\left[\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}-\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left((D-1) u_{x}^{n}+C u_{x x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}\right)\right]
$$

2. If we approximate the term $u^{n, 1}$ of the right-hand side to time $t^{n}$ considering (3.6) with the first two terms of the expansion, then we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 1}= & u^{n}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma \tau(D-1) u^{n}-\gamma \tau(D-1)\left(u^{n}+\left(t^{n}+\gamma \tau-t^{n}\right) u_{t}^{n}+O\left((\gamma \tau)^{2}\right)\right) \\
& -\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left((D-1) u_{x}^{n}+C u_{x x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}\right) \\
= & u^{n}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}-\gamma^{2} \tau^{2}(D-1) u_{t}^{n} \\
& -\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left((D-1) u_{x}^{n}+C u_{x x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

A.2. Second IMEX stage. The second IMEX stage (3.7) is now given in this case by:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\left[C u_{x}^{n}+(D-1) u^{n}\right]+\alpha_{1}\left[C u_{x}^{n, 1}+(D-1) u^{n, 1}\right] \\
& +\frac{1-\gamma}{2}\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 1}\right]+\gamma\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, applying the general equation (3.8), we obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \alpha_{1} u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 2}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau} \\
& +\gamma\left[C u_{x}^{n}+(D-1) u^{n}\right]+\gamma\left[-C u_{x}^{n, 2}-(D-1) u^{n, 2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, now we are going to calculate the derivative of $u^{n, 2}$ using the IMEX scheme. Note that from these third-order approximations of the derivatives in $\tau$ and applying Section 3.2, we know that

$$
\frac{u_{x}^{n, 2}-u_{x}^{n}}{\tau}=\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right) \frac{u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}}{\gamma \tau}
$$

being $\frac{u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}}{\gamma \tau}$ the replacement we did in the first stage. Therefore:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \alpha_{1} u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma(-(D-1))\left(u^{n, 2}-u^{n}\right)+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau} \\
& -C\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right)\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}$ is calculated with (3.5). Then, the linear equation for this stage reads

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 2}-u^{n}= & \alpha_{1} \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma}-C\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right) \tau\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right) \\
& +\gamma \tau(-(D-1))\left(u^{n, 2}-u^{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We propose the following ways to solve it:

1. Solving it analytically we get the following expression for $u^{n, 2}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 2}= & u^{n}+\frac{\tau}{1+\tau \gamma(D-1)}\left[\alpha_{1} u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 2}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}\right. \\
& \left.-C\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right)\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

2. Passing the term $u^{n, 2}$ of the right hand side to time $t^{n}$ by using (3.6), we obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 2}=u^{n}+ & \alpha_{1} \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma}-C\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right) \tau\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right) \\
& +\gamma \tau(-(D-1))\left(u^{n}+\frac{1+\gamma}{2} \tau u_{t}^{n}\right)+\gamma \tau(D-1) u^{n} \\
= & u^{n}+\alpha_{1} \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma}-C\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right) \tau\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right) \\
& -\gamma \tau^{2}(D-1) \frac{1+\gamma}{2} u_{t}^{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

A.3. Third IMEX stage. The third IMEX stage (3.10) reads

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 3}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \left(1-\alpha_{2}\right)\left[C u_{x}^{n, 1}+(D-1) u^{n, 1}\right]+\alpha_{2}\left[C u_{x}^{n, 2}+(D-1) u^{n, 2}\right] \\
& +\beta_{1}\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 1}\right]+\beta_{2}\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 2}\right]+\gamma\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 3}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Following Section 3.3 this results in

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 3}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \left(1-\alpha_{2}\right) u_{t}^{n, 1}+\beta_{2} u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 3}+\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau} \\
& +\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right)\left[\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}-\frac{\alpha_{1}}{\gamma} u_{t}^{n, 1}-u_{t}^{n, 2}-\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma^{2} \tau}\right] \\
& +\gamma\left[C u_{x}^{n}+(D-1) u^{n}\right]+\gamma\left[-C u_{x}^{n, 3}-(D-1) u^{n, 3}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

It remains to evaluate the directional derivatives of $u^{n, 3}$, we use (3.12), so that:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 3}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \left(1-\alpha_{2}\right) u_{t}^{n, 1}+\beta_{2} u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 3}+\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau} \\
& +\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right)\left[\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}-\frac{\alpha_{1}}{\gamma} u_{t}^{n, 1}-u_{t}^{n, 2}-\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma^{2} \tau}\right] \\
& +\gamma\left[C u_{x}^{n}+(D-1) u^{n}\right] \\
& +\gamma\left[-C\left(u_{x}^{n}+\frac{u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}}{\gamma}\right)-(D-1) u^{n, 3}\right] \\
= & \left(1-\alpha_{2}-\frac{\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right) \alpha_{1}}{\gamma}\right) u_{t}^{n, 1}+\alpha_{2} u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 3}+\gamma(-(D-1))\left(u^{n, 3}-u^{n}\right) \\
& +\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1-\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau} \\
& +\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left[\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}\right]-C\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Again, we need to solve the linear equation. As before, here we propose two ways:

1. The algebraic solution of the linear equation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 3}= & u^{n}+\frac{\tau}{1+\gamma \tau(D-1)}\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(1-\alpha_{2}-\frac{\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right) \alpha_{1}}{\gamma}\right) u_{t}^{n, 1}+\alpha_{2} u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 3} \\
\quad+\left[\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1-\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\right] \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau} \\
\quad+\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left[\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}\right]-C\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)
\end{array}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

2. Taking $u^{n, 3}$ on the right hand side to time $t^{n}$ leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 3}-u^{n}= & \left(1-\alpha_{2}-\frac{\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right) \alpha_{1}}{\gamma}\right) \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\alpha_{2} \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 3} \\
& +\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1-\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma} \\
& +\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left[u^{n, 2}-u^{n}\right]-C \tau\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)-\gamma \tau^{2}(D-1) u_{t}^{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

B. One-dimensional nonlinear PDE with source terms. In this section, the proposed boundary treatment strategy is applied to the following diffusive Burgers equation with source terms solved in Section 5.2 of the article,

$$
u_{t}+\partial_{x} f(u)=\partial_{x} g\left(u_{x}\right)+h(u, x, t)
$$

where

$$
f(u)=\frac{u^{2}}{2}, \quad g\left(u_{x}\right)=D u_{x}, \quad h(u, x, t)=p(x, t) u
$$

being $D \in \mathbb{R}$ the diffusion parameter. Therefore,

$$
u_{t}=-u u_{x}+D u_{x x}+p(x, t) u
$$

B.1. First IMEX stage. The first IMEX stage (3.3) reads

$$
\frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}=\left[-u^{n} u_{x}^{n}+p(x, t) u^{n}\right]+\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 1}\right]
$$

According to (2.17), the explicit part operator is

$$
\xi^{n, i}(x)=-u^{n, i} u_{x}^{n, i}+p\left(x, t^{n, i}\right) u^{n, i}
$$

Substituting the derivative (3.5) on (3.4) for this particular case, and replacing $u_{x x x}^{n, 1}$ with $u_{x x x}^{n, 0}$ we end up with

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 1}= & u^{n}+\gamma \tau\left(u_{t}^{n, 1}+p(x, t) u^{n}-u^{n} u_{x}^{n}\right)-\gamma \tau p\left(x, t^{n, 1}\right) u^{n, 1} \\
& +\gamma \tau u^{n, 1}\left[u_{x}^{n}+\gamma \tau\left(-\left(u_{x}^{n}\right)^{2}-u^{n} u_{x x}^{n}+p^{\prime}\left(x, t^{n}\right) u^{n}+p\left(x, t^{n}\right) u_{x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In order to deal with this nonlinear equation in $u^{n, 1}$ we propose:

1. Obtaining the exact solution:

$$
u^{n, 1}=\frac{u^{n}+\gamma \tau\left(-u^{n} u_{x}^{n}+p\left(x, t^{n}\right) u^{n}+u_{t}^{n, 1}\right)}{1-\gamma^{2} \tau^{2}\left(-\frac{p\left(x, t^{n, 1}\right)}{\gamma \tau}+\frac{u_{x}^{n}}{\gamma \tau}-\left(u_{x}^{n}\right)^{2}-u^{n} u_{x x}^{n}+p^{\prime}\left(x, t^{n}\right) u^{n}+p\left(x, t^{n}\right) u_{x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}\right)}
$$

2. Solving by transforming the terms $u^{n, 1}$ in the right side to terms in $u^{n, 0}$ according to the approximation obtained in (3.6):

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 1}= & u^{n}+\gamma \tau\left(u_{t}^{n, 1}+p(x, t) u^{n}-u^{n} u_{x}^{n}\right) \\
& +\gamma \tau\left[u^{n}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n}\right]\left[-p\left(x, t^{n, 1}\right)+u_{x}^{n}\right. \\
& \left.\quad+\gamma \tau\left(-\left(u_{x}^{n}\right)^{2}-u^{n} u_{x x}^{n}+p^{\prime}\left(x, t^{n}\right) u^{n}+p\left(x, t^{n}\right) u_{x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

B.2. Second IMEX stage. In this case, the second IMEX stage (3.7) reads:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\left[-u^{n} u_{x}^{n}+p\left(x, t^{n}\right) u^{n}\right]+\alpha_{1}\left[-u^{n, 1} u_{x}^{n, 1}+p\left(x, t^{n, 1}\right) u^{n, 1}\right] \\
& +\frac{1-\gamma}{2}\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 1}\right]+\gamma\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

As previously, we substitute (3.9) on (3.8) for this particular case, leading to

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 2}= & u^{n}+\alpha_{1} \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma}+\gamma \tau\left[-u^{n} u_{x}^{n}+p\left(x, t^{n}\right) u^{n}\right] \\
& +\gamma \tau u^{n, 2}\left(u_{x}^{n}+\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right) \frac{u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}}{\gamma}-p\left(x, t^{n, 2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now it is needed to solve the nonlinear equation, we proceed in two ways:

1. Obtaining the analytical solution for the denominator being not null:

$$
u^{n, 2}=\frac{u^{n}+\tau\left(\alpha_{1} u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 2}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}+\gamma\left[\xi^{n}\right]\right)}{1+\gamma \tau p\left(x, t^{n, 2}\right)-\gamma^{2} \tau^{2}\left(u_{x}^{n} / \gamma \tau+\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\left[\xi_{x}^{n}\right]+\alpha_{1}\left[\xi_{x}^{n, 1}\right]+\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\left[D u_{x x x}^{n}\right]\right)}
$$

2. If we approximate $u^{n, 2}$, in terms of $u^{n}$ as described in (3.6):

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 2}= & u^{n}+\alpha_{1} \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma}+\gamma \tau\left[-u^{n} u_{x}^{n}+p\left(x, t^{n}\right) u^{n}\right] \\
& +\gamma \tau\left[u^{n}+\frac{1+\gamma}{2} \tau u_{t}^{n}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{2}\right)\right]\left(u_{x}^{n}+\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right) \frac{u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}}{\gamma}-p\left(x, t^{n, 2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

B.3. Third IMEX stage. Following the procedure described in Section 3.3, equation (3.11) with the substitution (3.12) is in this case

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 3}= & u^{n}+\left(1-\alpha_{2}-\frac{\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right) \alpha_{1}}{\gamma}\right) \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\alpha_{2} \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 3} \\
& +\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1-\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma}+\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left[u^{n, 2}-u^{n}\right] \\
& -\gamma \tau\left[u^{n} u_{x}^{n}-p\left(x, t^{n}\right) u^{n}\right]+\gamma \tau u^{n, 3}\left(u_{x}^{n}+\frac{u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}}{\gamma}-p\left(x, t^{n, 3}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This nonlinear equation has to be solved. Again, the two ways we propose are:

1. Solve the nonlinear equation for $u^{n, 3}$ :

$$
u^{n, 3}=\frac{u^{n}+\tau \cdot N u m}{D e n}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
N u m= & \left(1-\alpha_{2}\right) u_{t}^{n, 1}+\beta_{2} u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 3}+\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau} \\
& +\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right)\left[\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}-\frac{\alpha_{1}}{\gamma} u_{t}^{n, 1}-u_{t}^{n, 2}-\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma^{2} \tau}\right] \\
& +\gamma\left[\xi^{n}\right] \\
\text { Den }= & 1+\gamma \tau p\left(x, t^{n, 3}\right)-\gamma \tau^{2}\left[u_{x}^{n} / \tau+\left(1-\alpha_{2}\right) \xi_{x}^{n, 1}+\alpha_{2} \xi_{x}^{n, 2}+D u_{x x x}^{n}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

for Den $\neq 0$.
2. Approximate $u^{n, 3}$ of the right hand side in terms of $u^{n, 0}$ ending up with

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 3}= & u^{n}+\left(1-\alpha_{2}-\frac{\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right) \alpha_{1}}{\gamma}\right) \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\alpha_{2} \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 3} \\
& +\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1-\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma}+\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left[u^{n, 2}-u^{n}\right] \\
& -\gamma \tau\left[u^{n} u_{x}^{n}-p\left(x, t^{n}\right) u^{n}\right]+\gamma \tau\left[u^{n}+\tau u_{t}^{n}\right]\left(u_{x}^{n}+\frac{u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}}{\gamma}-p\left(x, t^{n, 3}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

As before, the second approach is numerically preferable, since there is no need to be alert with zero denominators in algebraic solutions.
C. Two-dimensional convective heat equation with source term. Finally, we show the detailed boundary treatment strategy for the following bidimensional heat equation solved in Section 5.3 of the article,

$$
u_{t}+\partial_{x} f_{1}(u)+\partial_{y} f_{2}(u)=\partial_{x} g_{1}\left(u_{x}, u_{y}\right)+\partial_{y} g_{2}\left(u_{x}, u_{y}\right)+h(u)
$$

where

$$
f_{1}=-C u, \quad f_{2}=-C u, \quad g_{1}=D u_{x}, \quad g_{2}=D u_{y}, \quad h=(2 D-1) u
$$

$C, D \in \mathbb{R}$. Therefore,

$$
u_{t}=C u_{x}+C u_{y}+(2 D-1) u+D u_{x x}+D u_{y y}
$$

Note that $u(x, y, t)=e^{-t} \sin (x+C t) \cos (y+C t)$ is the exact solution of this problem.

Initially, the first, second, and third IMEX stages are fully detailed in subsections C.1, C. 2 and C.3, respectively. Later, having in mind that third-order mixed derivatives in space need to be computed in the resulting strategies of the previous subsections, a proper way to approximate them is presented in subsection C.4. Finally, some plots of the numerical solutions are presented in subsection C.5.
C.1. First IMEX stage. The first IMEX stage reads

$$
\frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}=\left[C u_{x}^{n}+C u_{y}^{n}+(2 D-1) u^{n}\right]+\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 1}+D u_{y y}^{n, 1}\right]
$$

We assume that the PDE (C.2) is fulfilled at time $t^{n, 1}$, therefore:

$$
D u_{x x}^{n, 1}+D u_{y y}^{n, 1}=u_{t}^{n, 1}-C u_{x}^{n, 1}-C u_{y}^{n, 1}-(2 D-1) u^{n, 1}
$$

Substituting the diffusive term on the first stage (C.3):

$$
\frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}=\left[C u_{x}^{n}+C u_{y}^{n}+(2 D-1) u^{n}\right]+u_{t}^{n, 1}-C u_{x}^{n, 1}-C u_{y}^{n, 1}-(2 D-1) u^{n, 1}
$$

Now we compute the directional derivatives of $u^{n, 1}$ by taking derivatives on equation (C.3) respect to $x$ and $y$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{u_{x}^{n, 1}}{\gamma \tau}=\frac{u_{x}^{n}}{\gamma \tau}+\left[C u_{x x}^{n}+C u_{y x}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{x}^{n}\right]+D u_{x x x}^{n, 1}+D u_{y y x}^{n, 1} \\
& \frac{u_{y}^{n, 1}}{\gamma \tau}=\frac{u_{y}^{n}}{\gamma \tau}+\left[C u_{x y}^{n}+C u_{y y}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{y}^{n}\right]+D u_{x x y}^{n, 1}+D u_{y y y}^{n, 1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting these derivatives on (C.4) we end up with

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 1}-u^{n}= & \gamma \tau\left[u_{t}^{n, 1}-(2 D-1)\left(u^{n, 1}-u^{n}\right)\right] \\
& -\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left\{C u_{x x}^{n}+C u_{y x}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n, 1}+D u_{y y x}^{n, 1}\right\} \\
& -\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left\{C u_{x y}^{n}+C u_{y y}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{y}^{n}+D u_{x x y}^{n, 1}+D u_{y y y}^{n, 1}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we apply Propositition 3.1 to compute the partial derivatives $\delta_{x, y}^{(k)} u^{n, l}=\delta_{x, y}^{(k)} u^{n}+\mathcal{O}(\tau)$. As a result

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 1}-u^{n}= & \gamma \tau\left[u_{t}^{n, 1}-(2 D-1)\left(u^{n, 1}-u^{n}\right)\right] \\
& -\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left\{C u_{x x}^{n}+C u_{y x}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}+D u_{y y x}^{n}\right\} \\
& -\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left\{C u_{x y}^{n}+C u_{y y}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{y}^{n}+D u_{x x y}^{n}+D u_{y y y}^{n}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, to solve this equation, once again we propose:

1. Analytical solution for $u^{n, 1}$, the final formula is

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 1}=u^{n}+ & \frac{1}{1+\gamma \tau(2 D-1)}\left[\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}\right. \\
& \left.-\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left\{C u_{x x}^{n}+C u_{y x}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}+D u_{y y x}^{n}\right\}\right) \\
& \left.-\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left\{C u_{x y}^{n}+C u_{y y}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{y}^{n}+D u_{x x y}^{n}+D u_{y y y}^{n}\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

2. Application of Proposition 3.1 to approximate $u^{n, 1}$ with $u^{n, 0}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 1}= & u^{n}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}-\gamma^{2} \tau^{2}(2 D-1) u_{t}^{n} \\
& -\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left\{C u_{x x}^{n}+C u_{y x}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{x}^{n}+D u_{x x x}^{n}+D u_{y y x}^{n}\right\} \\
& -\gamma^{2} \tau^{2} C\left\{C u_{x y}^{n}+C u_{y y}^{n}+(2 D-1) u_{y}^{n}+D u_{x x y}^{n}+D u_{y y y}^{n}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

C.2. Second IMEX stage. The second IMEX stage for the two-dimensional case reads

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\left[C u_{x}^{n}+C u_{y}^{n}+(2 D-1) u^{n}\right]+\alpha_{1}\left[C u_{x}^{n, 1}+C u_{y}^{n, 1}+(2 D-1) u^{n, 1}\right] \\
& +\frac{1-\gamma}{2}\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 1}+D u_{y y}^{n, 1}\right]+\gamma\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 2}+D u_{y y}^{n, 2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Following Section 3.2, $u^{n, 2}$ can be expressed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \alpha_{1} u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma(-(2 D-1))\left(u^{n, 2}-u^{n}\right)+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau} \\
& -C\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right)\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)-C\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right)\left(u_{y}^{n, 1}-u_{y}^{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, to deal with this linear equation we propose:

1. Analytical solution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 2}=u^{n}+\frac{\tau}{1+\gamma \tau(2 D-1)} & {\left[\alpha_{1} u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 2}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}\right.} \\
& \left.-C\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right)\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)-C\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right)\left(u_{y}^{n, 1}-u_{y}^{n}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

2. If we move $u^{n, 2}$ on the right hand side to time $t^{n}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 2}= & u^{n}+\alpha_{1} \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}-\gamma \tau^{2}(2 D-1) \frac{1+\gamma}{2} u_{t}^{n}+\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma} \\
& -C \tau\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right)\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)-C \tau\left(\frac{1+\gamma}{2}\right)\left(u_{y}^{n, 1}-u_{y}^{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In both cases, for $u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}$ and $u_{y}^{n, 1}-u_{y}^{n}$, we use (C.5) and (C.6), respectively, passing the times $t^{n, 1}$ to $t^{n}$.

C.3. Third IMEX stage. In this case, the third stage reads:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 3}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \left(1-\alpha_{2}\right)\left[C u_{x}^{n, 1}+C u_{y}^{n, 1}+(2 D-1) u^{n, 1}\right]+\alpha_{2}\left[C u_{x}^{n, 2}+C u_{y}^{n, 2}+(2 D-1) u^{n, 2}\right] \\
& +\beta_{1}\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 1}+D u_{y y}^{n, 1}\right]+\beta_{2}\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 2}+D u_{y y}^{n, 2}\right]+\gamma\left[D u_{x x}^{n, 3}+D u_{y y}^{n, 3}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Following Section 3.3 we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u^{n, 3}-u^{n}}{\tau}= & \left(1-\alpha_{2}-\frac{\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right) \alpha_{1}}{\gamma}\right) u_{t}^{n, 1}+\alpha_{2} u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 3}-\gamma(2 D-1)\left(u^{n, 3}-u^{n}\right) \\
& +\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1-\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau} \\
& +\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left[\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}\right]-C\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)-C\left(u_{y}^{n, 1}-u_{y}^{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we propose two approaches:

1. Algebraic solution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 3}= & u^{n}+\frac{\tau}{1+\gamma \tau(2 D-1)}\left[\left(1-\alpha_{2}-\frac{\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right) \alpha_{1}}{\gamma}\right) u_{t}^{n, 1}+\alpha_{2} u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma u_{t}^{n, 3}\right. \\
& \left.+\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1-\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma \tau}\right. \\
& \left.+\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{u^{n, 2}-u^{n}}{\tau}\right)-C\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)-C\left(u_{y}^{n, 1}-u_{y}^{n}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

2. Taking $u^{n, 3}$ on the right into time $t^{n}$ would result in:

$$
\begin{aligned}
u^{n, 3}= & u^{n}+\left(1-\alpha_{2}-\frac{\left(\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}\right) \alpha_{1}}{\gamma}\right) \tau u_{t}^{n, 1}+\alpha_{2} \tau u_{t}^{n, 2}+\gamma \tau u_{t}^{n, 3}-\gamma \tau^{2}(2 D-1) u_{t}^{n} \\
& +\left(\alpha_{2}+\beta_{1}-1-\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{1-\gamma}{2}-\alpha_{1}\right)\right) \frac{u^{n, 1}-u^{n}}{\gamma} \\
& +\frac{\beta_{2}-\alpha_{2}}{\gamma}\left[u^{n, 2}-u^{n}\right]-C \tau\left(u_{x}^{n, 1}-u_{x}^{n}\right)-C \tau\left(u_{y}^{n, 1}-u_{y}^{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

C.4. Approximations for $u_{x x x}^{n}, u_{y y y}^{n}, u_{y z x}^{n}$ and $u_{x x y}^{n}$. Since $k=2$ for the third-order IMEX LDG scheme here considered, $\hat{u}_{x x}$ and $\hat{u}_{y y}$ are constant over each volume along the $x$ and $y$ directions, respectively. To compute $u_{x x x}^{n}$ for points in the boundary, we take a finite difference approximation of the second derivative over the first derivative $\hat{u}_{x}$. Let us assume that $(x, y) \in \Gamma(\Omega)$ and also $(x, y) \in \square_{i j}$. To shorten the notation, in the approximations below we denote

$$
\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i \pm a, j \pm b}=\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i \pm a, j \pm b}\left(x \pm a \Delta_{i} x, y \pm b \Delta_{j} y\right)
$$

More precisely, the approximations are:

- If possible, we take centered approximation

$$
\hat{u}_{x x x}(x, y) \approx \frac{\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+1, j}-2\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i, j}+\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-1, j}}{\left(\Delta_{i} x\right)^{2}}
$$

- Otherwise, we take backward or forward approximations.

The computation of $u_{y y y}^{n}$ is done analogously.
Finally, we sketch the approximation of the third-order mixed derivatives with $u_{x x y}^{n}$. The idea is to compute the mixed derivative of $\hat{u}_{x}$. As an example, the approximation of $u_{x x y}^{n}$ at points over the south boundary is performed as follows,

- If the point does not belong to volumes at the corners,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \hat{u}_{x x y}(x, y) \approx \\
& \frac{-\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+1, j+2}+4\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+1, j+1}-3\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+1, j}+\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-1, j+2}-4\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-1, j+1}+3\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-1, j}}{4 \Delta_{i} x \Delta_{j} y} .
\end{aligned}
$$

- If the point belongs to the south-west corner,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{u}_{x x y}(x, y) \approx & -\frac{-\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+2, j+2}+4\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+2, j+1}-3\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+2, j}}{4 \Delta_{i} x \Delta_{j} y} \\
& +4 \frac{-\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+1, j+2}+\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+1, j+1}-3\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i+1, j}}{4 \Delta_{i} x \Delta_{j} y} \\
& -3 \frac{-\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i, j+2}+4\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i, j+1}-3\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i, j}}{4 \Delta_{i} x \Delta_{j} y} .
\end{aligned}
$$

- Otherwise (south-east corner),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{u}_{x x y}(x, y) \approx & 3 \frac{-\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i, j+2}+4\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i, j+1}-3\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i, j}}{4 \Delta_{i} x \Delta_{j} y} \\
& -4 \frac{-\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-1, j+2}+4\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-1, j+1}-3\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-1, j}}{4 \Delta_{i} x \Delta_{j} y} \\
& +\frac{-\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-2, j+2}+4\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-2, j+1}-3\left(\hat{u}_{x}\right)_{i-2, j}}{4 \Delta_{i} x \Delta_{j} y}
\end{aligned}
$$

The approximations over the remaining boundaries are done in the same way. An analogous approach is used for the approximations of $u_{y y x}^{n}$.
C.5. Boundary plots. In this section, we present some boundary plots for the numerical experiment of Section 5.3. In Figure 7, contour plots show the final time errors in space in the cases without and with boundary treatment. Large boundary spatial errors (concerning interior errors), appearing when no boundary treatment is considered, vanish with the developed method. Finally, in Figure 8, some one-dimensional cuts of Figure 7 in the middle of the spatial domain are shown.

Fig. 7. Contour plots for the spatial errors considering $N, M=80$ with the same data of Table 3, $t=T$.

FIG. 8. Spatial errors for some cuts of Figure 7.

abstract:
In this article, we propose novel boundary treatment algorithms to avoid
order reduction when implicit-explicit Runge-Kutta time discretization is used
for solving convection-diffusion-reaction problems with time-dependent
Di\-richlet boundary conditions. We consider Cartesian meshes and PDEs with
stiff terms coming from the diffusive parts of the PDE. The algorithms treat
boundary values at the implicit-explicit internal stages in the same way as the
interior points. The boundary treatment strategy is designed to work with
multidimensional problems with possible nonlinear advection and source terms.
The proposed methods recover the designed order of convergence by numerical
verification. For the spatial discretization, in this work, we consider Local
Discontinuous Galerkin methods, although the developed boundary treatment
algorithms can operate with other discretization schemes in space, such as
Finite Differences, Finite Elements or Finite Volumes.
